    Progress and Developments in Tau Aggregation Inhibitors for Alzheimer Disease

    • Bruno Bulic*†
      • , 
    • Marcus Pickhardt‡
      • , and 
    • Eckhard Mandelkow‡§∥
    View Author Information
    † Laboratory of Organic Synthesis of Functional Systems, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Brook-Taylor-Strasse 2, 12489 Berlin, Germany
    ‡ DZNE (German Center for Neurodegenerative Diseases), Ludwig-Erhard-Allee 2, 53175 Bonn, Germany
    § CAESAR Research Center, Ludwig-Erhard-Allee 2, 53175 Bonn, Germany
    ∥ Max-Planck-Institute for Neurological Research, Hamburg Outstation, c/o DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22607 Hamburg, Germany
    *Telephone: +49-30 2093-7464. E-mail: [email protected]
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2013, 56, 11, 4135–4155
    Publication Date (Web):March 13, 2013

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Pharmacological approaches directed toward Alzheimer disease are diversifying in parallel with a growing number of promising targets. Investigations on the microtubule-associated protein tau yielded innovative targets backed by recent findings about the central role of tau in numerous neurodegenerative diseases. In this review, we summarize the recent evolution in the development of nonpeptidic small molecules tau aggregation inhibitors (TAGIs) and their advancement toward clinical trials. The compounds are classified according to their chemical structures, providing correlative insights into their pharmacology. Overall, shared structure–activity traits are emerging, as well as specific binding modes related to their ability to engage in hydrogen bonding. Medicinal chemistry efforts on TAGIs together with encouraging in vivo data argue for successful translation to the clinic.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Alzheimer disease (AD, also known commonly as Alzheimer’s disease) is developing into the third most frequent pathology afflicting humans after cancer and cardiovascular diseases, mostly because of the worldwide increase in life expectancy. Symptoms may evolve during the progression of the disease, from the so-called mild cognitive impairments (MCI) at early stages to advanced dementia at later stages, placing patients under gradually increasing stress. Unfortunately, disease-modifying drugs able to stop or cure the disease are not yet available, leaving physicians with only symptom-alleviating medications in hand.
    To address this issue, investigations on the cause and mechanism of AD have significantly intensified over the past decade, leading to novel concepts in neurobiology. Indeed, most of the recent clinical trials have been based on the amyloid cascade hypothesis, stipulating the occurrence of aggregation-prone Aβ42 proteins and subsequent β-amyloid plaques as the source of the disease.(1) Strikingly, the very close spatial correlation between neuronal loss and Tau-based neurofibrillary tangles in patient’s brains has been long overlooked. It points to a higher layer of complexity and supports the hypothesis that Tau might play a prominent role in AD neurodegeneration.(2) Indeed, reducing Tau expression in mouse models that express mutant proaggregation forms of APP (amyloid precursor protein) was found to protect the mice from cognitive deficits normally associated with high cerebral Aβ load.(3, 4) Moreover, in inducible Tau cell lines, interruption of Tau expression rescued cells from toxic effects. Conversely, mutations in the human Tau gene generating aggregation-prone Tau variants are linked to tauopathies, indicating that Tau aggregation might be neurotoxic per se.(5-8)
    Hypotheses on the molecular interplay between Tau and Aβ leading to the reported neurotoxicity are just starting to emerge and have been extensively reviewed elsewhere.(9, 10) The hierarchical position of Aβ in the toxicity cascade, traditionally upstream of Tau, has been also challenged by the observation that pathological Tau might appear in the locus coeruleus at early stages preceding amyloid plaques.(11) Yet it might become essential to further define the molecular form of Tau that mediates toxicity (monomer, oligomer, polymer, combined with posttranslational modifications), while current models favor a key role for oligomers.(12-14)
    For future drug development, the recent series of suspended clinical trials on lack of efficacy or safety calls for a revision of the current therapeutic concepts for AD.(15-17) Currently, programs based on the amyloid cascade hypothesis still occupy a predominant place in pharmaceutical product pipelines.(18-22) Among at least 17 small molecules in clinical trial or preclinical development phase, 10 candidates target Aβ production through APP processing by β- and γ-secretases, 6 compounds target Aβ aggregation, and only 1 (Rember)(23) targets Tau aggregation.(22, 24)
    Alternatively, Aβ clearance has been addressed through immunotherapy using either active or passive immunization with Aβ antigens or anti-Aβ antibodies, respectively. These studies were particularly instructive on the impact of Aβ-amyloids at advanced stages of AD. Follow-up studies on the terminated trial with the AN1792(25) antigen indicated no evidence of cognitive efficacy in spite of extensive amyloid plaques clearance and no reduction of NFTs.(25) Outcomes of trials with passive immunization are now eagerly awaited; however, preliminary results from a phase III trial with bapineuzumab(26) show missed primary end points in 1100 ApoE4 carriers. Thus, it is reasonable to search for innovative therapies aimed at Tau as a complement to the available therapeutic arsenal, in a disease that might appear as an Aβ-linked tauopathy.(6, 17, 27-31)
    Although Tau-directed immunotherapy approaches did not reach clinical trials yet, active and passive immunization in mouse models appears promising.(32) Knowledge about abnormally phosphorylated sites in tauopathies allowed the design of disease-specific antigens such as the Tau195–213 (targeting the epitope of antibody AT8, pS202 + pT205) or Tau379–408 (epitope of PHF1, pS396 + pS404).(33, 34) Because mouse models recapitulating a specific abnormal phosphorylation pattern are not yet available, active immunization trials have been mostly performed on mice expressing FTDP-17 mutations such as the P301L or P301S or familial AD hTau/M146L-PS1. Administration of antigens resulted in extensive reduction of Tau tangle load, raising questions about the mode of action.(33-36) Additionally, passive immunization using the PHF-1 antibody appears promising as well.(37, 38) This implies that antibodies permeate to some extent the blood–brain barrier (BBB), consistent with results using FITC-labeled antibodies.(34, 39)
    As complement to immunotherapy, several original Tau-directed approaches have been explored, from reduction of Tau absolute level to inhibition of Tau aggregation or control of Tau posttranslational modifications such as phosphorylation, acetylation, cleavage, or nitration.(40-42) Promoting Tau degradation deserves special attention, since cell homeostasis is frequently disturbed upon aging.(43) Autophagy is the major pathway of Tau clearance, and therefore, up-regulation of autophagy is a promising approach.(44-46) In addition Tau has been identified as a client for molecular chaperones such as Hsp70 and Hsp90, leading to stabilization of misfolded proteins or redirection toward proteasomal degradation. For instance, inhibition of Hsp90 leads to increased proteosomal degradation of Tau, thus providing a valuable therapeutic target.(47-51)
    The best documented function of Tau is the binding to and subsequent stabilization of axonal microtubules, negatively regulated by phosphorylation at several serine, threonine, and tyrosine sites. Therefore, besides the gain of toxic function of aggregated Tau, a possible loss of function has been proposed, leading to destabilization of microtubules and impaired axonal transport.(31) Thus, microtubule stabilizing agents such as paclitaxel, epothilone D,(29) and the octapeptide NAPVSIPQ (“NAP peptide”)(50) are all promising disease modifying drugs for AD.
    In this review article we focus on the recent evolution in the development of nonpeptidic small molecule Tau aggregation inhibitors (TAGIs), starting with a short overview of the current structural models for their targets in the aggregated state and the advancement stage in clinical trials.

    Molecular Models of Tau Aggregates and Oligomers

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Knowledge of the molecular structure of aggregates is invaluable for the understanding of the protein self-assembly mechanisms and for the rational design of aggregation inhibitors. However, this task is complicated by the natively unfolded nature of Tau.(52, 53) X-ray scattering, FTIR, CD, and fluorescence spectroscopy revealed a mostly disordered structure but also pointed to a localized folding which brings the N- and C-terminal domains to form a “paper clip”.(54) Solution NMR studies of full-length Tau (hTau40, Figure 1) confirmed the lack of ordered strucuture but also highlighted regions with transient secondary structure, notably the hexapeptide motifs with high β-propensity in the repeat domains, short transient polyproline helices upstream of the repeat domain, and a short α helix near the C-terminus.(55, 56) Altogether, only a tiny fraction of the Tau protein, the hexapeptide motifs in repeats R2 and R3, are responsible for the abnormal self-assembly process, and the paper-clip conformation is expected to have a protective effect against Tau aggregation by shielding the hexapeptide motifs.(56)
    In addition to AD, aggregation of Tau is characteristic of several diseases known as tauopathies. These diseases are heterogeneous, with spatio–temporal differences linked not only to brain areas but also to the spliced variants of aggregated Tau.(59) This variability translates into various fibril morphologies as seen by electron microscopy and atomic force microscopy (AFM), with different twists and diameters. In AD, Tau filaments have typically a twist repeat of 80 nm and a width varying between 12 and 22 nm. Although the term “paired helical filament”, originally coined by Kidd et al.,(60) suggests two filaments wrapped around one another, a better interpretation is that of a single filament with a roughly ellipsoidal cross section, twisted around its longitudinal axis.(61) The packing order of Tau subunits in the filaments is not known in detail except that the region around the hexapeptide motifs forms several short parallel β-sheets in a cross-β conformation, as seen by EPR and solid-state NMR,(62)(58) while X-ray diffraction shows two reflections at 4.8 and 10 Å thought to correspond to the longitudinal interstrand and lateral intersheet spacing, respectively.(63) Strikingly, this reflection pattern is shared by most fibrillar aggregates, irrespective of the amino acid sequence of the constitutive proteins.(7) This generic structure provides a rationale for the surprising structural similarities in small molecules targeting amyloids. Indeed, it is known that aggregation inhibitors of a specific amyloidogenic peptide are also potential aggregation inhibitors of a wide variety of other amyloidogenic peptides(64-66) and that histological dyes such as thioflavin S or Congo red(67) bind to aggregates in at least 15 genetically unrelated disorders.(68)
    Recently, a breakthrough in modeling Tau aggregates has been achieved using the aggregation-prone segment of Tau within its repeat domain. This VQIVYK sequence is located in the PHF6 hexapeptide motif (Figure 1) and has been proposed to nucleate the aggregation of Tau via formation of β-sheet interactions. Indeed, β-sheet breaker mutations in the hexapeptide motifs such as prolines render the protein incompetent for assembly, as well as deletion of the positively charged K280 lysine engaged in localized electrostatic interactions hindering Tau self-assembly.(69) Conversely, mutations within the hexapeptide motif that enhance the β-sheet propensity such as the P301L mutation found in FTDP-17 promote Tau aggregation.(70) On the basis of this structural information, aggregation of Tau can be inhibited either by mutations disrupting the β structure with “antiaggregant” mutations, e.g., I308P,(71) or by small molecule compounds interacting with the β-sheet region (Akoury et al.).(215)
    As developed further below, the identification of hot spots required for Tau self-assembly is supporting the feasibility of chemical Tau aggregation inhibition, as deduced from the development of protein–protein interactions inhibitors.(73)
    Remarkably, the short 306VQIVYK311 segment, when isolated from the whole protein, has been amenable to microcrystallization and thereby to structure determination at atomic resolution using X-ray microcrystallography.(74) The resolved structure confirmed not only in-register β-strands running parallel to the fibril axis but also a novel fold perpendicular to the fibril axis, named steric zipper because of the shape-complementary interdigitations with amino acids side chains, forming a tightly packed dry interface (Figure 2a).(74) Adding up the hydrogen bonds network to the hydrophobic dry interface provides the driving force leading to extremely stable fibrillar aggregates. Moreover, NMR experiments have highlighted the intermolecular interactions of the nucleating hexapeptide motifs VQIINK and VQIVYK motifs, in line with previous findings showing that mutations within these hexapeptide motifs are sufficient to inhibit or promote aggregation.(57, 69, 75) The involvement of the VQIVYK motif in PHFs has been recently confirmed using solid state NMR, and most importantly, the method also allowed investigation of PHFs formed by the 99 amino acids K19 Tau construct showing multiple interacting regions besides the nucleating core.(58) Indeed, 18 amino acids out of 99 appeared involved in the rigid core of the fibrils, encompassing, besides the PHF6 motif V306-K311, the sequences V313-L315 and either K317-C322 or K317-K321. Interestingly, the single cysteine C322 of the K19 sequence can be involved in two distinct disulfide bridges, stabilizing the aggregated conformation, in line with previous finding showing dependency of aggregation on redox conditions.(76, 77)
    Besides PHFs, novel oligomeric forms with ill-defined structures appeared following the isolation of nonfibrillar Aβ forms in AD patients. These smaller structures, putatively formed by dimers, trimers, and larger multimers of Aβ, were found to induce strong synaptic toxicity.(7, 79-81) Oligomeric Tau species have been characterized and also display strong neurotoxicity through a yet unclear mechanism.(6, 12) The peptidic arrangement in oligomers is expected to be distinct from the stacking in fully aggregated fibrillar forms, as indicated by the high resolution model of an hexameric fragment of αB-crystallin recently obtained by X-ray crystallography, showing a β-sheet rich structure forming a barrel (Figure 2b), a species presumably branching off-pathway from fiber formation (Figure 03).(78, 82) Noteworthy, this structure was specifically recognized by the anti-Aβ conformational antibody A11, hinting at a generic structure eventually shared with Tau oligomers.(78, 83) At the dimer level, Tau has been isolated using photochemical cross-linking with benzophenonemaleimide in order to lock and stabilize the oligomeric structure, showing an antiparallel Tau-Tau conformation.(14) Further, annular hexamers and higher order oligomers have been reported, also with marked neurotoxicity. In the development of TAGIs, it is therefore becoming increasingly important to document the molecular target, which could be monomeric, oligomeric, or aggregated Tau (Figure 03).
    Moreover, the availability of atomic resolution structures of oligomeric and fibrillar Tau opens the door to rational design using chemoinformatic approaches.(84, 85) In a seminal study, structures of aggregated VQIVYK peptides cocrystallized with several Tau binders such as curcumin and DDNP(85) have been obtained (47 and 48, Figure 15) paving the way for further in silico developments. In parallel, macrocyclic and all-d-amino acid peptide inhibitors for Tau aggregation could be obtained using structure-based design.(86, 87)

    Progress toward Clinical Trials: Tau and Aβ Aggregation Inhibition

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    To date, most of drug development targeting aggregation inhibition has been directed toward Aβ. Because valuable precursors pave the way for TAGIs, their current stage of clinical development is described below. At the forefront of TAGIs that successfully moved from preclinical development to clinical trials are methylene blue(84) (1, Figure 4) and demethylated derivatives such as azure A (6, Figure 4).(23, 88)
    In a phase II trial on 321 patients with mild-to-moderate AD, TauRx reported that a compound derived from 1 may slow or halt the progression of the disease. At 24 weeks, patients treated with 1 declined 5.4 points less on the ADAS-cog scale than placebo. At 50 weeks, no significant cognitive decline could be detected anymore while the placebo group worsened 6.8 points. With several decades of utilization as a medication for diverse human pathologies, the safety profile of 1 is abundantly documented.(89, 90) The long-term administration of 1 in congenital methemoglobinemia and as antimalarial agent does not induce severe side effects and involves only dizziness or nausea.(89) Although adverse effects in connection with light exposure are not documented, the photosensitizing properties of 1 might call for prudence.(91) From a chemical point of view, two major forms of the molecule are in equilibrium, depending on the redox potential of the solution: the oxidized cationic form (blue, 1) and the reduced colorless form, also called leuco-methylene blue (2, Figure 4).(92) In an oxygen rich environment, the equilibrium is largely shifted toward the oxidized form 1. Noteworthy, while the leuco form is classified as a phenothiazine, the predominantly oxidized form 1 is closer to polyaromatics such as 8, 9, or reduced anthraquinones (Figure 4).
    Phenothiazines such as the antipsychotic drugs 5 and 3 are nonaromatic tricyclic structures with two aromatic rings bridged through nitrogen and sulfur atoms, while 9 is a planar aromatic structure (Figure 4).(93) Strikingly, true phenothiazines such as 3, 4, and 5 are incompetent to inhibit Tau aggregation, while aromatic anthracene-type compounds such as 1, 6, or even quinacrine mustard were all found to be active with comparable low micromolar potencies (Figure 4).(65) Therefore, the classification of 1 in the group of phenothiazines might be inadequate as far as its TAGIs properties are considered.
    From a pharmacokinetic viewpoint, the ADME data analysis (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion) suggests a high oral bioavailability at 72% despite its hydrophilic character, probably because of the dispersion of the positive charge on the molecule by resonance.(94, 95) Investigations on the pharmacokinetics of 1, administrated as prophylaxis of ifosfamide-associated encephalopathy, indicate a 5 h half-life, a high volume distribution, and significant brain penetration.(96) Nevertheless the bioavailability after oral administration was found to go with significant liver accumulation, as also observed for multiple cyanine dyes described below.(97)
    Recently the experimental drug LMTX (structure not disclosed), derived from 1, has been introduced into a global phase 3 clinical trial against the behavioral-variant of frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) characterized by early changes in personality, also known as Pick disease. The substance was chemically optimized with regard to tolerability and bioavailability in order to enable the use of higher concentrations compared to 1 (press release, TauRx Therapeutics). While phase III trials in AD are anticipated, the mode of action of the drug remains enigmatic. In vitro investigations on full length Tau provided variable potencies, with demethylated derivatives such as 6, thionine, and tolonium chloride being occasionally more potent than 1 (IC50 = 69–108 nM at inhibitor/Tau ratio 5/1 versus IC50 = 3.4 μM for 1) or equally potent (IC50 = 1.9–2.6 μM). Depending on the assay and Tau isoforms, a potency for 1 as low as 31 μM could be observed.(90) Note that because of the optical properties of 1 and its derivatives, e.g., 6, which shows a high light absorption potential at wavelengths below 350 nm and between 620 and 760 nm (Figure 5), many assays monitoring fluorescence or absorption effects in vitro or in vivo may fail in the presence of 1.
    Moreover, Tau aggregation inhibition with 1 might be dependent on the model investigated and aggregation stage. For instance, 1 failed to inhibit prefibrillar Tau-dependent toxicity in Tau-P301L zebrafish or Tau phosphorylation in 3xTg-AD mice;(98, 99) however, on the contrary, the Tau level was significantly lowered in organotypic brain slices at nanomolar concentrations of 1.(100) These differences between in vitro and in vitro systems could be explained by the pleiotropic action of 1 which binds, for example, to ATP-binding pockets of cellular proteins.(101) Keeping in mind the moderate TAGI potency of 1, it has been proposed that 1 pleiotropy partly accounts for the reported improvements in behavioral studies in mice, since 1 is also an MAO inhibitor and NO-synthase inhibitor.(92, 102) Most importantly, the redox activity of 1 was proposed to compensate complex IV deficits in the mitochondrial respiratory chain, thereby promoting cell survival. Noteworthy, the redox properties of 1 might largely contribute to the Tau aggregation inhibitory effect. Indeed, it has been previously reported that redox oscillators could inhibit Tau aggregation unspecifically through peroxide generation.(103) The production of reactive oxygen species might also arise from light exposure of photosensitizers such a 1 or porphyrines.(91) Predominantly, in the presence of oxygen and reducing agents typically found in vivo, such as NAD(P)H, thioredoxins, or glutathione, 1 behaves as a redox oscillator, cycling between the reduced and oxidized forms, thereby producing peroxides (Figure 4).(104) This property is shared by most of the anthracene-type compounds and is also pertinent for the evaluation of the anthraquinone-based TAGIs described below (Figure 9).
    One of the major hurdles in the development of aggregation inhibitor is that different “aggregopathies” are based on similar structural principles, namely, the inappropriate assembly of β strands into pathological oligomers and fibers. This makes it difficult to identify specific inhibitors that discriminate between different aggregating proteins and yet do not interfere with physiological β structures. Thus, aggregation inhibitors are often designed and tested in parallel for several neurodegenerative diseases.(84, 87) Given that only a single member of the TAGI family reached clinical trials so far, a brief glance at the current stage of development in Aβ-aggregation inhibitors might be relevant for feasibility evaluation.
    Tramiprosate(105) (10, Figure 6) was developed as a GAG mimetic (glycosaminoglycan) following the initial observation that sulfated GAGs such as heparin are abundant in amyloid plaques and NFTs. In retrospect, given the difficulties observed with anti-Aβ immonotherapies, the failure of 10 in phase III is explainable.(16) However, the compound was successful at lowering CSF Aβ42 in mild-to-moderate AD, thus proving target engagement. The inhibitor was found to bind preferentially to the soluble monomeric form of Aβ at the highly charged HHQK motif.(106)
    The next most currently advanced candidate, ELND005(107) (AZD-103, 11, a scyllo-inositol(108) analogue, Figure 6), developed by Transition Therapeutics in partnership with Elan, completed phase II trials on mild AD after fulfilling safety and tolerability tests and is now expected to enter phase III. According to in vitro investigations, scyllo-inositol,(108) but not its stereoisomers such as myo-, epi-, and chiro-inositols, was found to inhibit Aβ aggregation by selectively binding to the Aβ42 C-terminus for shielding or by redirecting the aggregation toward a nontoxic oligomeric form.(109) This mode of action is reminiscent of the polyphenol epi-gallocatechine gallate (EGCG(110, 111) or Sunphenon, 12 Figure 6), currently in phase II, even though this last compound associates with a different segment of the Aβ peptide, the hydrophobic core.(111-113) For more information on the mode of action and structure–activity relationship for polyphenols-derived TAGIs, see the section on polyphenols below.
    Metal chelators have been reported to inhibit aggregation of Aβ in vitro. Prana Biotechnology has developed PBT-2 (structure not disclosed), an 8-hydroxyquinoline copper/zinc ionophore derived from clioquinol(114) (13, Figure 6).(115, 116) The phase II trial with the drug candidate showed the ability to reduce Aβ42 CSF levels and adequate BBB permeability. In parallel, the compound was reported to significantly reduce the level of phosphorylated Tau in animal models. While PBT-1 was markedly toxic at high doses, the derived drug candidate successfully passed safety and tolerability tests. Noteworthy, besides aggregation inhibition, the compound is claimed to restore metal homeostasis in the brain.(117)
    ProteoTech recently received FDA approval to conduct a phase I clinical trial with Exebryl-1 (structure not disclosed). Interestingly, besides inhibition of Aβ aggregation, the compound was also found to inhibit aggregation of the Tau repeat domain (TauRD) with IC50 = 10.5 μM at a 1:1 Tau/inhibitor ratio and could disassemble full length Tau with EC50 = 3.56 μM at a 1:2 Tau/inhibitor ratio. The mode of action was investigated by CD spectroscopy, indicating that the compound might bind to soluble monomers and block the conformational change from random coil to β-sheet structure (press release, retrieved from http://www.proteotech.com/pdfs/exebryl-1_poster.pdf).
    Samaritan Pharmaceuticals entered phase I trials with SP-233 or caprospinol(115) (14, Figure 6), a neurosteroid found to protect neuronal mitochondria from Aβ42 induced toxicity.(118, 119) Although the compound is claimed to be an Aβ oligomerization inhibitor, its potency remains undisclosed. However, a mode of action has been proposed, involving the binding of the molecule to residues 23–42 of Aβ42.(119)
    The pyridazine scaffold (Figure 6) has been identified by Daiichi Sankyo Pharmaceuticals as a weak Aβ42-aggregation inhibitor with IC50 = 100 μM at 4:1 compound/Aβ42 ratio.(120) It was later found to inhibit Aβ oligomerization.(121) Derivative SEN1269(122) (15, Figure 6), currently owned by BTG Pharma, was further developed by Senexis Pharma, improving the pharmacokinetics and BBB permeability. Evidence of direct binding of these compounds to the monomeric Aβ and to oligomers has been obtained using surface plasmon resonance on N-terminus-biotinylated Aβ, supporting the concept of monomer binders.(122)
    Altogether, the successful advancement of several Aβ aggregation inhibitors in clinical trials paves the way for development of TAGIs. One straightforward strategy for the discovery of new active molecules for Tau aggregation inhibition continues to be the screening of compound libraries containing sufficient structural diversity. Identification of hits generally enables the subsequent medicinal chemistry efforts necessary to reach compounds featuring the desired properties, i.e., optimized inhibitory potencies and pharmacokinetics.

    HTS for Tau Aggregation Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Several approaches have been used to perform high or medium throughput screens for Tau aggregation inhibitors. They include fluorescence-based assays of Tau aggregation using thioflavin S as an indicator,(72) filter assays to segregate soluble and insoluble protein,(64) sarkosyl treatment followed by quantification of sarkosyl-soluble and insoluble Tau protein,(65) quantification of filament length and amount by transmission electron microscopy,(123) and fluorescence depolarization of labeled Tau which distinguishes diffusible from aggregated molecules.(124)
    In our studies on Tau aggregation inhibitors, the Tau construct K19 was used which comprises the three repeat domains of the fetal human isofom hTau23 (Figure 1).(72) This construct corresponds to the core of the PHF structure and contains the VQIVYK hexapeptide motif which supports the β-sheet structure that promotes aggregation.(57) The initial screening for active aggregation inhibitor compounds and validation of the results was accomplished by a thioflavin S(125) fluorescence assay where the emission of thioflavin S fluorescence is highly increased at 521 nm (excitation, 440 nm) in the presence of PHFs (Figure 7). This fluorescence increase is proportional to the extent of aggregation.
    A library of 200 000 compounds was screened both for inhibition of Tau aggregation and for induced disassembly of Tau aggregates,(72) an additional feature that is rarely considered among commonly screened compounds. The compound set used for the primary screen was selected according to Lipinski’s rules. Tau protein was incubated overnight under proaggregation conditions in the presence of the screened compound (Figure 7). After addition of thioflavin S, the aggregation was quantified by measurement at 440 nm excitation and 512 nm emission wavelengths. The secondary screen (disassembly of preformed Tau fibrils) was performed by incubation of PHFs in the presence or absence of compounds overnight at 37 °C followed by measurement of the ThS fluorescence of the remaining fibrils. The obtained Z-factor of 0.81 confirmed the reliability of the assay.(126) The results were verified with other assays (electron microscopy, filter/pelleting assay) as well as with other Tau constructs and isoforms.
    In AD, Tau is not only aggregated but also highly phosphorylated, raising the question of the relationship between these two properties. It is often assumed that phosphorylation is a trigger for aggregation (hence, the search for kinase inhibitors as a means to prevent aggregation).(41) However, the evidence remains ambiguous. The properties of phosphorylated Tau with regard to detachment from microtubules and aggregation into fibrils depend on a complex phosphorylation pattern, which might contribute or hinder the aggregation, depending on its extent and localization. The screening was performed with unphosphorylated recombinant Tau which provided fibers highly similar to those purified from brain tissues of Alzheimer patients and whose structure has been previously assessed by electron microscopy and spectroscopic methods, indicating that the in vitro aggregation is a reliable PHF model.(127, 128)
    In the primary ThS screen the compounds were tested for their potential self-fluorescence at the given excitation and emission wavelengths. All compounds that showed a higher fluorescence signal in the absence of protein than in the presence were excluded from further testing. To exclude possible quenching or ThS-displacement effects, the substances were also tested in “dye-free” assays such as pelleting and filter assays, intrinsic tryptophan fluorescence, or electron microscopy.
    As mentioned above, the ability not only to inhibit Tau aggregation but also to disassemble preformed aggregates was included in the selection parameters for the screening of compounds, leading to the elimination of 99.96% of the library compounds. The identified hits were able to induce a PHF disassembly with up to 80% efficiency at 60 μM compound. These hits were classified in clusters according to their chemical structures. Details on the inhibitory activities obtained from the N-phenylamines, anthraquinones, phenylthiazolylhydrazides (PTHs), and thioxothiazolidinones (rhodanines) were described previously.(72, 129-132) The chemistry primarily aimed at elucidating the requirements for improved inhibitory potencies led to the structure–activity relationship (SAR) of the two last mentioned compound clusters (PTHs and rhodanines). The compounds were subsequently tested on a neuronal cell model of Tau aggregation(71) and more recently proved to be effective in C. elegans expressing proaggregant Tau species(133) as well as in organic typical slices.(134)

    Polyphenols and Anthraquinones

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Polyphenols are characterized by the presence of one or more hydroxyl groups (−OH) bound to an aromatic benzene ring (Figure 8). These substances are often biosynthesized by plants, and dietary alimentation supplemented with green tea, chocolate, olive oil, or red wine is highly recommended by dieticians worldwide for their potential antibiotic, antidiabetic, or neuroprotective activities.(135)
    As a result of HTS screen campaigns for amyloid aggregation inhibition, numerous polyphenols have been identified that inhibit aggregation of a wide variety of amyloidogenic peptides such as α-synuclein, IAPP, Aβ40, PrPsc, and Tau.(65, 112, 136-138) For instance, myricetin(65) (19) has IC50 = 1.2 μM on Tau aggregation inhibition and investigations on the binding mode in vitro clearly indicate that they interfere with the elongation phase in fibril assembly.(66, 139, 140) In a comparable way, the polyphenol (−)-epi-gallocatechine gallate(111) (12, Figure 8) was found to redirect the aggregation pathway of Aβ toward nontoxic spherical oligomers by binding to monomers or fibrillar species and was also found to inhibit the aggregation of a wide variety of other amyloidogenic proteins, such as α-synuclein, Aβ, prion protein PrP, yeast prion sup35, lysozyme, transthyretin, and Tau (IC50 = 1.8 μM for Tau).(65, 111, 112) We have performed experiments to determine the effect of 12 on different variants of Tau. In the case of the three-repeat construct K19, the antiaggregation IC50 was at 3.9 μM, similar to the value described above. However, with full-length hTau40 the IC50 value was in excess of >200 μM, i.e., 50-fold higher. This unexpected result can be explained if 12 has a high affinity to regions of Tau outside the repeat domain, which effectively “dilutes” the concentration of the compound by distributing it over the entire polypeptide chain. Similar “dilution” effects have been observed with a number of different compounds, depending on the distribution of low or high affinity binding sites along the length of the Tau chain (for examples, see ref 141). In this context, it is important to bear in mind that Tau is natively unfolded and thus offers many potential interaction sites for small molecules. These considerations emphasize the importance of defining which Tau construct or isoform and which conditions (concentration, buffer) are used in the assay.
    Catechins, specifically 12, are present in high concentration in green tea leaves and grape seeds, and recent reports also confirmed the ability of grape seeds extracts to inhibit Tau at stoichiometric 12/Tau concentration.(142, 143) Although the extract is a complex mixture of polyphenols, it is reasonable to attribute this effect to 12 and pyrogallol (17, Figure 8).(144) Strikingly, a comparative structure–activity relationship analysis between active and inactive polyphenols indicates that the gallate moiety is required for activity, since the gallate-free catechin itself was found to be inactive (12 IC50 = 1.8 μM, 18 IC50 ≥ 200 μM, Figure 8).(65) More specifically, trisubstituted phenols, a pattern also known as pyrogallol (red, Figure 8), are significantly enriched scaffolds within active polyphenolic aggregation inhibitors. Indeed, studies with 12 on Aβ aggregation inhibition indicate that the pyrogallol vicinal triols are required for inhibitory activity and that the compound loosely targeted hydrophobic areas in the Aβ peptide at positions 14–24 and 27–37.(145) Furthermore, epicatechin gallate, 12, and gallocatechin gallate, which all contain the gallate moiety, were found to be active, whereas catechin and 18(112) were not (Figure 8). Surprisingly, epigallocatechin appeared inactive, in spite of presenting the pyrogallol moiety, hinting at additional binding determinants. However, this structure–activity relationship is broadly supported upon examination of 48 flavonoids evaluated on α-synuclein aggregation inhibition.(136)
    Finally, it is unexpected that the high polarity of flavonoids proves to be compatible with the highly hydrophobic regions in aggregated proteins, raising questions about their molecular interactions with the target. A plausible explanation has been proposed based on molecular dynamics with 19(137) using the high resolution structure of Sup-35 obtained by X-ray microcrystallography. The obtained model indeed shows a coordination of the pyrogallol hydroxyl groups in 19 to the peptide backbone amides of GNNQQNY Sup-35.(137)
    Lastly, the antiaggregation properties of polyphenols cannot be completely dissociated from their typical antioxidant and radical quenching activities. Pro-oxidant activities have also been reported under specific conditions, and the generation of radicals could also be involved in the observed antiaggregation effect. Issues about the specificity of action should be addressed before proceeding further with clinical investigations in order to avoid potential side effects through unspecific binding. From a clinical point of view, the oral bioavailability of polyphenols is notoriously variable, with the gylcosylated forms being the least absorbed because of their very high polarity, while few aglycone polyphenols proved to be extensively absorbed.(146) For instance, the bioavailability of 12 and its BBB permeability is moderate, and it is not yet clear if 12 itself or metabolites were detected in the brain.(147) However, the physicochemical characteristics of this compound class, especially their low log P, hold promise for lead development. Indeed, hydrophilicity is a valuable property frequently observed among drugs of natural origin but not among synthetic molecules which are typically highly hydrophobic and little specific.(148-150)
    Anthraquinones are close analogues of polyphenols in their oxidized quinone forms (Figure 9A, red); however, upon reduction by NADP(H) in vivo or in vitro by reducing agents such as DTT, they become comparable to anthracene-type compounds such as 1 (Figure 9A, blue).(103)
    Several anthraquinones display aggregation inhibition abilities on Tau and Aβ40 but are best known as intercalating cytostatics that are successfully used in anticancer therapies.(65, 139) Precisely because of their DNA intercalating properties, anthraquinones must be handled with care. Our LDH cytotoxicity data confirm substantial toxicity in vitro.(141) The ADME properties (absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion) of this compound class have been abundantly documented and also converge on their limited intestinal permeability. For this reason, highly hydrophilic anthracyclines such as 24(141) (Adriamycin) equipped with a daunosamine sugar are generally administrated intravenously.(151, 152) As mentioned above for parent anthracene compounds and 1, the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) is well documented and was found to cause false positive hits in Tau aggregation assays in the presence of DTT.(103, 153) However, this effect is highly variable, and daunorubicin or doxorubicin(103) appeared DTT insensitive. In our own screen performed without DTT, several anthraquinones indeed appeared as potent TAGIs. The five compounds depicted in Figure 9B were all able to inhibit the aggregation of the K19 Tau construct and to induce the disaggregation of preformed aggregates, with IC50 values between 1.1 and 2.4 μM and DC50 values (disassembly inducing half-maxima) between 2.2 and 3.8 μM, irrespective of the molecular substitution pattern.(141) Several anthraquinones have been assayed on various Tau constructs, such as wtK19 (three repeat Tau), wtK18 (four repeat), K18ΔK280 (proaggregant four-repeat Tau), as well as full length hTau24 and fetal three-repeat isoform hTau23. As expected from previous studies indicating that the four repeat K18 is less amyloidogenic than the three repeat K19, anthraquinones more potently inhibited the aggregation of wtK18 than wtK19.(76) Moreover, decreased potency with the proaggregation mutant K18ΔK280 versus wtK18 supports the expected aggregation-promoting effect of the ΔK280 mutation. The overall potencies for inhibition of aggregation with hTau23 and hTau24 were of comparable magnitude with inhibition of the repeat domain constructs except for 20(141) and 22,(141) which appeared unable to inhibit hTau24 aggregation, suggesting that their mode of action might not be shared by the other anthraquinones. Indeed, their vicinal diols and triols are reminiscent of pyrogallol described above for polyphenols (Figure 8). Finally, compounds showing potency in Tau aggregation inhibition did not necessarily show activity in Tau depolymerisation, raising questions about the respective mechanisms. Lastly, a pharmacophore mapping with several anthraquinones known as Aβ aggregation inhibitors yielded a three-point model with aromatic rings bound to hydrophobic regions and the sugar moiety supporting hydrogen bond donors and acceptors.(139)

    Rhodanine-Based Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Rhodanines were identified as TAGIs in our screen, and the scaffold was further explored via the synthesis of a focused library.(129) The structure–activity relationship (SAR) was obtained following modifications on the heterocycle core itself. Rhodanines (R1 = S and R2 = S, 25, Figure 10), thiohydantoin (R1 = S and R2 = N), thioxooxazolidine (R1 = S and R2 = O), oxazolidinedione (R1 = O and R2 = O), and hydantoin (R1 = O and R2 = N) were synthesized and assayed for activity on Tau aggregation inhibition and disaggregation of preformed Tau aggregates as described above.
    Rhodanines appeared to be the most potent aggregation inhibitors, while hydantoins were the least active (IC50 = 22.6 μM).(129) The depolymerization of preformed Tau fibrils was also evaluated, with the objective to obtain compounds having the ability to clear up the cells of their tangle load. Gratifyingly, the disassembly inducing half-maxima (DC50) were recorded in the low micromolar range (DC50 = 0.1 μM). The mode of action of this compound class is, however, still poorly understood. As described above for polyphenols, hydrogen bonds might play a predominant role. Indeed, the rhodanine core is sometimes considered as a carboxylic acid bioisoster, able to engage in hydrogen bond and van der Waals interactions.(154) Furthermore, the analysis of the substitution pattern on the flanking regions (Figure 10) showed preference for hydrogen bond donors and acceptors such as nitro groups, carboxylic acids, phenols, sulfonates/sulfonamides.(129) Interestingly, modifications of the side chains allowed observation of pronounced sensitivity toward the electron density distribution with, for instance, divergent activities between the furan ring in 26(129) and thiophene in 27(129) (Figure 10). The presence of aromatics on the side chain was also important, suggesting hydrophobic interactions and/or π-stacking.(66, 155) Next, we investigated the ADME profile of selected rhodanines in order to obtain compounds suitable for in vivo investigations. The rhodanine scaffold has a fair safety profile, according to numerous reports resulting from their evaluation in multiple assays.(156-166) However, the pleiotropism of rhodanines might be linked to undesirable chemical properties such as a susceptibility for covalent binding through conjugate addition to cysteins, calling for caution.(167) In an LDH assay, we assessed an acceptable safety profile with low cell toxicity (2–8%, LDH assay in N2A cells, incubation for 24 h at 10 μM compound) and determined the highest inhibitory potency on cells with charge-neutral benzimidazole 28(129) (Figure 10). Interestingly, the bioavailability and safety of a close structural analogue, epalrestat, have been extensively documented following a clinical study on diabetic neuropathy (3 years, 150 mg/day oral administration).(168) The extracted data support an acceptable pharmacologic profile (100 ± 22% bioavailability(168) and peak plasma concentration at 4.0 ± 0.9 μg/mL at 1.7 h after administration of a 50 mg oral dose, plasma half-life of 102 min).(169) Others have reported results from in vitro pharmacokinetic evaluations in line with our own data, showing an overall suitable profile for in vivo investigations.(161)
    Subsequently, investigations on a cell model of tauopathy allowed evaluation of the protective capabilities of rhodanine-based TAGIs against Tau-aggregation-induced cytotoxicity. Indeed, a major concern with disaggregation or inhibition of aggregation is the potential formation and stabilization of cytotoxic oligomers.(79, 170) The compounds were therefore tested on neuroblastoma N2a cell lines expressing the FTDP-17 proaggregation mutation ΔK280. Although the multimeric composition of Tau after incubation with rhodanines was not assessed, incubation of inducible N2a K18ΔK280 cells with compound 28 resulted in a clear reversal of toxicity caused by Tau aggregation,(129) an observation recently confirmed in vivo on C. elegans expressing proaggregant Tau species(133) as well as in a organotypic slice model derived from inducible Tau-transgenic mice.(134)

    Phenylthiazolylhydrazide Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    On the basis of hits obtained in an initial screen of 200 000 compounds, a ligand-based virtual screening yielded phenylthiazolylhydrazides (PTHs).(130) For this, a training set of 21 active compounds was selected in different chemical classes. The obtained pharmacophore model showed two aromatic rings at R1 and R3, a hydrophobic region on the thiazole ring and a hydrogen bond acceptor on the carboxyl amide (Figure 11A).
    The phenylthiazolylhydrazide scaffold was selected as best fit for further development through chemical modifications at R1–R3, providing 29(171) with gratifying activity at substochiometric inhibitor/Tau concentration (IC50 = 1.6 μM and DC50 = 0.7 μM at 10 μM K19). Valuable information about the binding mode of PTHs could be obtained using STD-NMR.(171) In this experiment, the saturation of the proton signals of the receptor (K18 Tau) transfers to its ligand (29) upon binding, resulting in the attenuation of the signal intensity of the ligands. The data indicate that 29 binds directly to monomeric Tau, probably shifting the Tau conformation toward off-pathway species, a mode of action reminiscent of 12 and Aβ as described above for polyphenols. The observed STD effects with 29 indicate a direct binding to K18 mediated through the aromatic ring of the imidazole ring, involving hydrophobic interactions reinforced by hydrogen bonding with the nitroaromatic and imidazole amines (Figure 11B).(171) Moreover, the STD-NMR experiments allowed the determination of the dissociation constant for 29 (Kd = 62 ± 12 μM), and complementary experiments using surface plasmon resonance (SPR) with immobilized K18 showed a fast 3700 M–1·s–1 association rate. Interestingly, the binding of 29 was found to be incompletely reversible on SPR, suggesting some level of covalent binding, although the PTH scaffold does not present any obvious Michael acceptor site.(171)
    Recently, derivatives combining the hydrazine moiety with the above-described pyrogallol moiety have been reported (30,(172) Figure 11C). Several derivatives displayed a marked selectivity for Tau versus Aβ aggregation inhibition, thereby providing efficient stains for histochemical studies.
    From a pharmacokinetic aspect, numerous bioactive thiazolylhydrazide scaffolds have been reported in the literature because of their analgesic, antibacterial, antifungal, or antiproliferative activities.(173-175) However, the scaffold might be sensitive to cyp P450-mediated oxidative cleavages on both the thiazole and hydrazine moieties.(176) Hydrazine/hydrazides are also potential producers of radical oxidative species (ROS) following oxidative cleavage of the hydrazine N–N bond. The formation of reactive acyl radicals has been reported for the antituberculosis isoniazid and will require further testing.(177-182)

    N-Phenylamine Inhibitors

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Further TAGIs were identified in the N-phenylamines compound class.(131) Their structure–activity relationship is reminiscent of the one described above for rhodanines and PTHs, with strong involvement of hydrogen bonds presented by nitro/carboxylic acids combined with hydrophobic interactions provided by the aromatic rings. Structurally comparable compounds such as the carbazole 33(139) (Figure 12) have been identified as Aβ aggregation inhibitors, for which an in silico pharmacophore mapping confirmed hydrophobic and hydrogen bond contributions.(139)
    Chemically, the nonplanar conformation linked to the rotation axis around the carbon–nitrogen bond translates into lower potencies in vitro and in cells compared to the two compound classes discussed above (rhodanines and phenylthiazolylhydrazides). Although the pharmacokinetic properties of this compound class have not been reported, the similarities with anthranilic acids used as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (niflumic acid and 34, Figure 12) might suggest some level of toxicity at high doses. The presence of anilines might also raise safety issues linked to their liver oxidation by cyp P450.(183)
    The activities of N-phenylamine TAGIs were investigated on an inducible N2a cell model of tauopathy. Using the aggregation-promoting property of the proaggregant mutation ΔK280, neuroblastoma N2a cells expressing the four repeat Tau repeat domain K18ΔK280 gradually form PHFs. Upon incubation with 10 μM 32(131) over 5 days, the ThS signal in cells decreased by 70% compared to untreated control and, most importantly, cell viability returned to normal as assessed by LDH release.

    Benzothiazoles

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Benzothiazoles are heteroaromatic structures with a 1,3-thiazole ring, found in well-known histology dyes such as ThS and ThT(184) or cyanine dyes (Figure 13) and display high affinities for β-sheet structures.
    Cyanine dyes are characterized by a polymethine chain linking two benzothiazoles, and several have been identified as Aβ and Tau aggregation inhibitors.(65, 185) Some benzothiazoles-based TAGIs present a cationic charge on the nitrogen, but this feature might not be essential for activity and probably only contributes to the planarity of the structure. Indeed, a charge-neutral ThT analogue, Pittsburgh compound B(186) (39, Figure 13), has an increased affinity toward Aβ40 compared to parent 38 (Ki(PiB) = 20 nM vs Ki(ThT) = 890 nM).(184, 186-189)
    An interesting structure–activity relationship has been reported for cyanine dyes after the synthesis of 35(185) (IC50 = 300 nM at 4 μM N2R4 hTau, Figure 13). Several modifications of the structure were found to drastically influence the Tau aggregation inhibitory potency when located at the thiazole heterocyle or at the polymethine bridge.(123) Therefore, it has been proposed that the potency of benzothiazole-based TAGIs might correlate with the π-electron density distribution on the molecule rather than with classical coordination through hydrophobic interaction or hydrogen bonds. In this context, a push–pull type polarizability might be required for inhibitory activity.(190) Unfortunately, this type of architecture often correlates with compounds that self-assemble face-to-face, also known as H-aggregation. A loss of inhibitory activity with 35 has been reported at high concentrations, caused indeed by the formation of H-aggregates. At low concentrations, 35 behaves as a TAGI by interfering with the fibril elongation phase, but at ≥30 μM the 35H-aggregates were observed to enhance Tau aggregation. To confirm the impact of inhibitor self-assembly, 35 was modified to provide a structure able to readily form a dimer through a closed clamshell structure (36(191) and 37,(191) Figure 13). The dimeric conformation suppressed the activity, consistent with the loss of activity of the H-aggregated form of the compound. This finding has been recently confirmed by changing the length of the linker (in red, Figure 13). In these experiments, compounds with four methylene units, a linker length known to hinder the closed monomer conformation, appeared more potent than the parent compound 36 with five methylene units favoring the closed conformation.(191)
    The pharmacology of benzothiazoles is relatively well documented owing to the use of 39 as imaging agent for in vivo amyloid deposition(186-188) or to the prescription of the benzothiazole drug riluzole(192) for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (NMDA receptor antagonist). Riluzole presents a satisfactory 60% bioavailabilty after oral ingestion with a 2 h peak plasma concentration, and a 12 h half-life supports a good in vivo stability.(192) The BBB permeability has been confirmed by HPLC analysis on mice brain extracts; however, the drug was also found to be a substrate for PgP efflux transporters.(193) On the other hand, the influence of the polymethine bridge is poorly documented and might be prone to first pass metabolism. Cyanine dyes might also complex to DNA.(194, 195) Indeed, numerous cyanine dyes are routinely used in laboratories as molecular probes for staining of nucleic acids and mitochondria.(196, 197) Finally, the low reduction potential of cyanine dyes impedes a potential involvement in redox cycling, a desirable characteristic too often neglected in drug development.(198)

    Aminothienopyridazines

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Aminothienopyridazines (APTZs) have been recently identified as potent inhibitors of P301L K18 Tau aggregation from the screening of a library of 292 000 compounds.(124) The finding was confirmed by complementary assays such as fluorescence polarization (FP), sedimentation, and electron microscopy, leading to the selection of two APTZs as lead candidates (41(124) IC50 = 5.1 μM and 42(124) IC50 = 6.3 μM at 15 μM K18P301L Tau, Figure 14).
    Besides validating similar kinetics of Tau aggregation with ThT and FP assays, it is expected that FP might help select inhibitors for the initial stage of Tau self-assembly. Analysis by size-exclusion chromatography (SEC) of the supernatant after incubation of hTau40 with APTZs did actually show the presence monomeric Tau but also the presence of stabilized oligomeric forms.(124) Therefore, the data suggest that APTZ prevent Tau aggregation by sequestering oligomers or more likely by remodeling oligomers toward off-pathway structures devoid of β-sheet structures, comparable to the mode of action reported above for 12 on Aβ.
    The further medicinal chemistry efforts in synthesis of a diversity-oriented library of APTZs allowed tracing of their structure–activity relationship, showing an interesting tolerability at the C1 position (40,(124) Figure 14), which allowed for tuning of the pharmacokinetic properties by introduction of esters, carboxylic acids, and amides.(199) By contrast, the thiophene ring and the N-phenylaromatic appeared to be very sensitive to modifications. As for cyanine dyes described above, polarizability through mesomeric effects might be involved, since para-substitutions with mesomeric donors such as −F, −Cl, and −OMe were well tolerated, while mesomeric acceptors such as −COOEt appeared detrimental.(124, 199)
    The APTZs were checked for red flags generally associated with promiscuous inhibitors and successfully passed tests aimed at filtering unspecific interactions mediated through H-aggregation or redox cycling activity. Although the compounds share some minor structural similitudes with hydrazinophtalazines and PTHs, ATPZs were found to be nontoxic up to 100 μM.(124) Further efforts to improve their use in vivo focused on the BBB permeability, leading to APTZs 43(199) and 44(199) with IC50 = 5.9 μM and IC50 = 8.1 μM, respectively (Figure 14).(199) These TAGIs were capable of reaching significant brain concentration in mice after oral or iv administration at 2 mg/kg, and compound 44 presented an excellent blood/plasma ratio (B/P = 1.6) and a 2.5 h half-life. Unfortunately, the low water solubility of the compound (32 μM) demanded further development, leading to 45(200) with improvements in both solubility (≥200 μM) and potency (IC50 = 2.5 μM at 20 μM K18 P301L, Figure 14), while the B/P ratio slightly deteriorated (B/P = 1.09).(200) However, lipophilic character generally correlates well with plasma binding, and 45 was indeed found sequestered at 95.7%. At 50 mg–1 kg–1 day–1 orally, free unbound 45 concentration in the brain was therefore below Tau stoichiometry (according to the author’s calculations). Yet the calculated concentration equals twice the IC50 value granting significant target engagement. With all the attractive features described above and only marginal toxicity at a 50 mg–1 kg–1 day–1 dose, the compound might be suitable for proof of concept studies in vivo.(200)

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Inhibition of protein–protein interactions (PPIs) is generally considered particularly challenging. Although some 650 000 PPIs are known to be involved in a cell’s organization, only a minute fraction has been addressed pharmacologically.(30, 73, 201, 202) Yet eminent examples are paving the way, starting with colchicines or paclitaxel, well-known inhibitor and promoter of microtubule assembly, commonly used in cancer chemotherapy. It is anticipated that comparable approaches could succeed in AD.(203, 204) However, difficulties in the development of protein–protein interaction inhibitors arise from the unfortunate conjunction of two factors, the first being the inadequate composition of the commercial small molecule libraries for HTS. Indeed, several decades of optimization for inhibitors typically directed toward enzymatic active sites might have biased the current compound libraries toward scaffolds not necessarily adapted for the inhibition of PPIs. The second limiting factor is directly linked to the nature of the PPIs interface. The relatively flat surfaces involved in protein–proteins interactions, averaging 2000 Å2, are typically much larger than the 60 Å2 average surface of small molecules.(205) Fortunately, vulnerable areas with high binding free energy, named hot spots, could be occasionally identified at the protein–protein interface, raising hopes about the druggability of such targets.(202) Previous investigations on Tau indicated the presence of such hot spots localized within the hexapeptide motif and support the feasibility of Tau aggregation inhibition with small molecules.(57, 69) Although the inhibitors reviewed here might target such area at the Tau-Tau interface, further investigations will be required to delineate with high resolution the Tau binding spot for TAGIs.
    While several compounds redirect the self-assembly toward off-pathway oligomeric forms, compounds binding to and stabilizing monomeric Tau in solution are scarce. With intrinsically disordered proteins such as Tau and Aβ, rational design of suitable binders indeed proves to be very challenging because of lack of epitopes. However, the 1:1 inhibitor/Tau stoichiometry often observed for maximal aggregation inhibition might point at significant binding to monomeric Tau, perhaps by recognition of the paper-clip-like folded state in solution.(56) For instance, the binding spots observed by STD-NMR involving a PTH inhibitor and the monomeric Tau peptide, as depicted in Figure 11B, illustrate that a direct interaction between small molecules and soluble monomeric peptides might be common among aggregation inhibitors and disaggregation promoters(171) However, binders from the thioflavin family such as 38 have been reported to only bind to aggregate forms, showing that multiple binding modes are likely.(206) Thioflavin S stains only fibrillar Tau aggregates but not small Tau oligomers, suggesting that the dye binds to large surfaces with ordered protein motifs (e.g., β sheets).
    Compounds that bind to soluble monomeric Tau might lock the protein in an aggregation-incompetent state, thus explaining their ability to inhibit aggregation. However, the mode of action for compounds binding to oligomers and fibrils appears more obscure. Moreover, discrepant potencies between Tau aggregation inhibition and disaggregation indicate two different modes of action for inhibition or disaggregation. Studies performed with fluorescently labeled Aβ fibrils in the presence of compound 12 were particularly instructive in that matter, showing a direct remodeling of the fibril itself, via an undetermined mechanism.(112)
    To gain further insights into the mode of action of TAGIs, the cocrystallization of inhibitors with their targets for X-ray analysis would provide direct evidence. However, alternative methods must be considered because of difficulties in obtaining crystalline materials with intrinsically disordered proteins such as Tau. A palliative solution circumventing the issue came with the determination of the Tau hexapeptide motifs responsible for aggregation.(85) Microcrystallization of this segment provided a simplified model for full-length Tau aggregates and allowed elucidation of the binding mode of three amyloid binders at atomic resolution. Among several investigated compounds, 46,(170)47,(207) and the dialkylaminonaphthylethylidene (48,(208) Figure 15) are known to bind to PHFs with high affinity and to also inhibit Tau aggregation at high concentrations,(209) whereas 47 is a polyphenolic stilbene and 48 shares the push–pull electronic architecture described above for benzothiazoles or APTZs (Figure 15A).
    According to X-ray microcrystallography, all three compounds were found positioned with their long axis parallel to the fiber axis. Furthermore the binding modes could be sorted into two classes, depending on the ability of the compounds to engage in hydrogen bonding. While the binding of charged compounds such as 46 appeared largely mediated through electrostatic interaction between sulfonates on 46 and Tau lysines, neutral or hydrophobic compounds such as 47 and 48 enter a hydrophobic tubelike cavity running parallel to the fiber axis (Figure 15B).(85) In line with this model, a comparable binding mode for 38 has been recently reported on crystallized β2-microglobulin.(210) The compound’s arrangement parallel to the fibril axis is also supported by recent NMR investigations and appears consistent with previous investigations using Congo red.(207, 211, 212) These investigations also predicted electrostatic interactions between positively charged residues on the fibril and the negatively charged sulfonic acids on Congo red. The binding was proposed to span perpendicularly across five peptide chains, based on the 19 Å distance between the Congo red sulfonic acids.(213)
    A powerful approach to analyze Tau–inhibitor interactions on full-length Tau comes from NMR spectroscopy, following the recent assignment of nearly all residues in Tau.(55, 214) This permits mapping of the regions of Tau interacting with small molecules, proteins (e.g., microtubules), other interactors,(215) or Tau itself, embedded in the structure of paired helical filaments.(58)
    Altogether, perceptible progress has been achieved after years of collective efforts aimed at deciphering the mode of action of TAGIs, as well as developing compounds with improved pharmacokinetic profiles. With several Aβ-aggregation inhibitors now facing clinical trials, it is about time to promote in vivo proof of concept studies for TAGIs.

    References

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    This article references 215 other publications.

    1. 1
      Hardy, J.; Selkoe, D. J. The amyloid hypothesis of Alzheimer’s disease: progress and problems on the road to therapeutics Science 2002, 297, 353– 356
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      The amyloid hypothesis of Alzheimer's disease: progress and problems on the road to therapeutics
      Hardy, John; Selkoe, Dennis J.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2002), 297 (5580), 353-356CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      A review. It has been more than 10 yr since it was first proposed that the neurodegeneration in Alzheimer's disease (AD) may be caused by deposition of amyloid β-peptide (Aβ) in plaques in brain tissue. According to the amyloid hypothesis, accumulation of Aβ in the brain is the primary influence driving AD pathogenesis. The rest of the disease process, including formation of neurofibrillary tangles contg. tau protein, is proposed to result from an imbalance between Aβ prodn. and Aβ clearance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xls1Cju7s%253D&md5=f7b8db1bc6f13e85f887b73f3042e86e
    2. 2
      Braak, H.; Braak, E. Neuropathological stageing of Alzheimer-related changes Acta Neuropathol. 1991, 82, 239– 259
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Neuropathological stageing of Alzheimer-related changes
      Braak H; Braak E
      Acta neuropathologica (1991), 82 (4), 239-59 ISSN:0001-6322.
      Eighty-three brains obtained at autopsy from nondemented and demented individuals were examined for extracellular amyloid deposits and intraneuronal neurofibrillary changes. The distribution pattern and packing density of amyloid deposits turned out to be of limited significance for differentiation of neuropathological stages. Neurofibrillary changes occurred in the form of neuritic plaques, neurofibrillary tangles and neuropil threads. The distribution of neuritic plaques varied widely not only within architectonic units but also from one individual to another. Neurofibrillary tangles and neuropil threads, in contrast, exhibited a characteristic distribution pattern permitting the differentiation of six stages. The first two stages were characterized by an either mild or severe alteration of the transentorhinal layer Pre-alpha (transentorhinal stages I-II). The two forms of limbic stages (stages III-IV) were marked by a conspicuous affection of layer Pre-alpha in both transentorhinal region and proper entorhinal cortex. In addition, there was mild involvement of the first Ammon's horn sector. The hallmark of the two isocortical stages (stages V-VI) was the destruction of virtually all isocortical association areas. The investigation showed that recognition of the six stages required qualitative evaluation of only a few key preparations.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaK387gtFOiug%253D%253D&md5=b3e2663c943c202f121efeb65527a280

    6. 6
      Crespo-Biel, N.; Theunis, C.; Van Leuven, F. Protein tau: prime cause of synaptic and neuronal degeneration in Alzheimer’s disease Int. J. Alzheimer’s Dis. 2012, 251426
      [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Protein Tau: prime cause of synaptic and neuronal degeneration in Alzheimer's disease
      Crespo-Biel, Natalia; Theunis, Clara; Van Leuven, Fred
      International Journal of Alzheimer's Disease (2012), (), 251426, 13 pp.CODEN: IJADAQ; ISSN:2090-0252. (Hindawi Publishing Corp.)
      A review. The microtubule-assocd. protein Tau (MAPT) is a major component of the pathogenesis of a wide variety of brain-damaging disorders, known as tauopathies. These include Alzheimer's disease (AD), denoted as secondary tauopathy because of the obligatory combination with amyloid pathol. In all tauopathies, protein Tau becomes aberrantly phosphorylated, adopts abnormal conformations, and aggregates into fibrils that eventually accumulate as threads in neuropil and as tangles in soma. The argyrophilic neurofibrillary threads and tangles, together denoted as NFT, provide the postmortem pathol. diagnosis for all tauopathies. In AD, neurofibrillary threads and tangles (NFTs) are codiagnostic with amyloid depositions but their sepd. and combined contributions to clin. symptoms remain elusive. Importantly, NFTs are now considered a late event and not directly responsible for early synaptic dysfunctions. Conversely, the biochem. and pathol. timeline is not exactly known in human tauopathy, but exptl. models point to smaller Tau-aggregates, termed oligomers or multimers, as synaptotoxic in early stages. The challenge is to molecularly define these Tau-isoforms that cause early cognitive and synaptic impairments. Here, we discuss relevant studies and data obtained in our mono- and bi-genic validated preclin. models, with the perspective of Tau as a therapeutic target.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XoslKmsbc%253D&md5=cbf293593895e434037019c401ae1a66
    7. 7
      Eisenberg, D.; Jucker, M. The amyloid state of proteins in human diseases Cell 2012, 148, 1188– 1203
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      The Amyloid state of proteins in human diseases
      Eisenberg, David; Jucker, Mathias
      Cell (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2012), 148 (6), 1188-1203CODEN: CELLB5; ISSN:0092-8674. (Cell Press)
      A review. Amyloid fibers and oligomers are assocd. with a great variety of human diseases including Alzheimer's disease and the prion conditions. Here we attempt to connect recent discoveries on the mol. properties of proteins in the amyloid state with observations about pathol. tissues and disease states. We summarize studies of structure and nucleation of amyloid and relate these to observations on amyloid polymorphism, prion strains, coaggregation of pathogenic proteins in tissues, and mechanisms of toxicity and transmissibility. Mol. studies have also led to numerous strategies for biol. and chem. interventions against amyloid diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xkt1Ggsbo%253D&md5=b141512d0e7f84a085bc7433f258d60a
    8. 8
      Kolarova, M.; Garcia-Sierra, F.; Bartos, A.; Ricny, J.; Ripova, D. Structure and pathology of tau protein in Alzheimer disease Int. J. Alzheimer’s Dis. 2012, 731526
      [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Structure and pathology of tau protein in Alzheimer disease
      Kolarova, Michala; Garcia-Sierra, Francisco; Bartos, Ales; Ricny, Jan; Ripova, Daniela
      International Journal of Alzheimer's Disease (2012), (), 731526, 13 pp.CODEN: IJADAQ; ISSN:2090-0252. (Hindawi Publishing Corp.)
      A review. Alzheimer's disease (AD) is the most common type of dementia. In connection with the global trend of prolonging human life and the increasing no. of elderly in the population, the AD becomes one of the most serious health and socioeconomic problems of the present. Tau protein promotes assembly and stabilizes microtubules, which contributes to the proper function of neuron. Alterations in the amt. or the structure of tau protein can affect its role as a stabilizer of microtubules as well as some of the processes in which it is implicated. The mol. mechanisms governing tau aggregation are mainly represented by several posttranslational modifications that alter its structure and conformational state. Hence, abnormal phosphorylation and truncation of tau protein have gained attention as key mechanisms that become tau protein in a pathol. entity. Evidences about the clinicopathol. significance of phosphorylated and truncated tau have been documented during the progression of AD as well as their capacity to exert cytotoxicity when expressed in cell and animal models. This paper describes the normal structure and function of tau protein and its major alterations during its pathol. aggregation in AD.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XosVensLg%253D&md5=32af79b01fe2aed9c1fe80ebbc0181de
    9. 9
      Ittner, L. M.; Gotz, J. Amyloid-beta and tau—a toxic pas de deux in Alzheimer’s disease Nat. Rev. Neurosci. 2011, 12, 65– 72
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      Amyloid-β and tau - a toxic pas de deux in Alzheimer's disease
      Ittner, Lars M.; Goetz, Juergen
      Nature Reviews Neuroscience (2011), 12 (2), 65-72CODEN: NRNAAN; ISSN:1471-003X. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Amyloid-β and tau are the two hallmark proteins in Alzheimer's disease. Although both amyloid-β and tau have been extensively studied individually with regard to their sep. modes of toxicity, more recently new light has been shed on their possible interactions and synergistic effects in Alzheimer's disease. Here, we review novel findings that have shifted our understanding of the role of tau in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease towards being a crucial partner of amyloid-β. As we gain a deeper understanding of the different cellular functions of tau, the focus shifts from the axon, where tau has a principal role as a microtubule-assocd. protein, to the dendrite, where it mediates amyloid-β toxicity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXjvFeq&md5=3eba522187f11cb5e7944dae5a025e55
    10. 10
      Zempel, H.; Thies, E.; Mandelkow, E.; Mandelkow, E. M. Abeta oligomers cause localized Ca(2+) elevation, missorting of endogenous Tau into dendrites, Tau phosphorylation, and destruction of microtubules and spines J. Neurosci. 2010, 30, 11938– 11950
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Aβ oligomers cause localized Ca2+ elevation, missorting of endogenous Tau into dendrites, Tau phosphorylation, and destruction of microtubules and spines
      Zempel, Hans; Thies, Edda; Mandelkow, Eckhard; Mandelkow, Eva-Maria
      Journal of Neuroscience (2010), 30 (36), 11938-11950CODEN: JNRSDS; ISSN:0270-6474. (Society for Neuroscience)
      Aggregation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and Tau protein are hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease (AD), and according to the Aβ-cascade hypothesis, Aβ is considered toxic for neurons and Tau a downstream target of Aβ. We have investigated differentiated primary hippocampal neurons for early localized changes following exposure to Aβ oligomers. Initial events become evident by missorting of endogenous Tau into the somatodendritic compartment, in contrast to axonal sorting in normal neurons. In missorted dendritic regions there is a depletion of spines and local increase in Ca2+, and breakdown of microtubules. Tau in these regions shows elevated phosphorylation at certain sites diagnostic of AD-Tau (e.g., epitope of antibody 12E8, whose phosphorylation causes detachment of Tau from microtubules, and AT8 epitope), and local elevation of certain kinase activities (e.g., MARK/par-1, BRSK/SADK, p70S6K, cdk5, but not GSK3β, JNK, MAPK). These local effects occur without global changes in Tau, tubulin, or kinase levels. Somatodendritic missorting occurs not only with Tau, but also with other axonal proteins such as neurofilaments, and correlates with pronounced depletion of microtubules and mitochondria. The Aβ-induced effects on microtubule and mitochondria depletion, Tau missorting, and loss of spines are prevented by taxol, indicating that Aβ-induced microtubule destabilization and corresponding traffic defects are key factors in incipient degeneration. By contrast, the rise in Ca2+ levels, kinase activities, and Tau phosphorylation cannot be prevented by taxol. Incipient and local changes similar to those of Aβ oligomers can be evoked by cell stressors (e.g., H2O2, glutamate, serum deprivation), suggesting some common mechanism of signaling.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtF2qsLnK&md5=c7f6cf2af311d01c746b16e31be0e4a4
    11. 11
      Braak, H.; Del Tredici, K. The pathological process underlying Alzheimer’s disease in individuals under thirty Acta Neuropathol. 2011, 121, 171– 181
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      The pathological process underlying Alzheimer's disease in individuals under thirty
      Braak Heiko; Del Tredici Kelly
      Acta neuropathologica (2011), 121 (2), 171-81 ISSN:.
      Brains of 42 individuals between the ages of 4 and 29 were examined with antibodies (AT8, 4G8) and silver stains for the presence of intraneuronal and extracellular protein aggregates associated with Alzheimer's disease. Thirty-eight of 42 (38/42) cases displayed abnormally phosphorylated tau protein (pretangle material) in nerve cells or in portions of their cellular processes, and 41/42 individuals showed no extracellular amyloid-β protein deposition or neuritic plaques-an individual with Down syndrome was the only exception. In 16/42 cases abnormal tau was found in the transentorhinal region, and in 3/42 cases this site was Gallyas-positive for isolated NFTs (NFT stage I). Of 26 cases that lacked abnormal tau in the transentorhinal region, 4 did not show pretangle material at subcortical sites. The remaining 22 of these same 26 cases, however, had subcortical lesions confined to non-thalamic nuclei with diffuse projections to the cerebral cortex, and, remarkably, in 19/22 individuals the pretangle material was confined to the noradrenergic coeruleus/subcoeruleus complex. Assuming the pretangle alterations are not transient and do not regress, these findings may indicate that the Alzheimer's disease-related pathological process leading to neurofibrillary tangle formation does not begin in the cerebral cortex but, rather, in select subcortical nuclei, and it may start quite early, i.e., before puberty or in early young adulthood.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3M7jvV2gtw%253D%253D&md5=fee9c22eed3f3ed66c22a7aa7215cb9d
