      206. 206
        LeVine, H., 3rd. Thioflavine T interaction with synthetic Alzheimer’s disease beta-amyloid peptides: detection of amyloid aggregation in solution Protein Sci. 1993, 2, 404– 410
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        206
        Thioflavin T interaction with synthetic Alzheimer's disease β-amyloid peptides: Detection of amyloid aggregation in solution
        LeVine, Harry, III
        Protein Science (1993), 2 (3), 404-10CODEN: PRCIEI; ISSN:0961-8368.
        Thioflavine T (ThT) assocs. rapidly with aggregated fibrils of the synthetic β/A4-derived peptides β(1-28) and β(1-40), giving rise to a new excitation (ex) (absorption) max. at 450 nm and enhanced emission (em) at 482 nm, as opposed to the 385 nm (ex) and 445 nm (em) of the free dye. This change is dependent on the aggregated state as monomeric or dimeric peptides do not react, and guanidine dissocn. of aggregates destroys the signal. There was no effect of high salt concns. Binding to the β(1-40) is of lower affinity, Kd 2 μM, while it sats. with a Kd of 0.54 μM for β(1-28). Insulin fibrils converted to a β-sheet conformation fluoresce intensely with ThT. A variety of polyhydroxy, polyanionic, or polycationic materials fail to interact or impede interaction with the amyloid peptides. This fluorometric technique should allow the kinetic elucidation of the amyloid fibril assembly process as well as the testing of agents that might modulate their assembly or disassembly.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXksVCntLo%253D&md5=d4bfff1cedf68a3c9379a87d88c3f97a
      207. 207
        Klunk, W. E.; Pettegrew, J. W.; Abraham, D. J. Quantitative evaluation of Congo red binding to amyloid-like proteins with a beta-pleated sheet conformation J. Histochem. Cytochem. 1989, 37, 1273– 1281
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        207
        Quantitative evaluation of Congo red binding to amyloid-like proteins with a beta-pleated sheet conformation
        Klunk, William E.; Pettegrew, Jay W.; Abraham, Donald J.
        Journal of Histochemistry and Cytochemistry (1989), 37 (8), 1273-81CODEN: JHCYAS; ISSN:0022-1554.
        The binding of Congo Red to several purified amyloid-like peptides having a β-pleated sheet conformation was quant. examd. Congo Red binds preferentially to the β-pleated sheet conformation of both insulin fibrils and poly-L-lysine. Congo Red does not bind nearly so well to poly-L-serine or polyglycine, despite the fact that these peptides also have a β-pleated sheet conformation. Binding to insulin fibrils was saturable with an apparent Bmax of 2 mol Congo Red/mol insulin fibrils and an apparent KD of 1.75 × 10-7M. Binding to β-poly-L-lysine was similar but had a much higher apparent Bmax of 43. Binding of Congo Red to β-poly-L-lysine was pH dependent and appeared to be detd. by the no. of protonated lysine residues in the 250 amino acid peptide. A new hypothesis is presented in which Congo Red binds to amyloid-like proteins via bonds between the 2 neg. charged sulfonic acid groups of Congo Red and 2 pos. charged amino acid residues of 2 sep. protein mols. which are properly oriented by virtue of the β-pleated sheet conformation of the peptide backbone.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXlt12ht7k%253D&md5=dbf3a9182aa87171b7a13a0e1dd529fd
      208. 208
        Petric, A.; Johnson, S. A.; Pham, H. V.; Li, Y.; Ceh, S.; Golobic, A.; Agdeppa, E. D.; Timbol, G.; Liu, J.; Keum, G.; Satyamurthy, N.; Kepe, V.; Houk, K. N.; Barrio, J. R. Dicyanovinylnaphthalenes for neuroimaging of amyloids and relationships of electronic structures and geometries to binding affinities Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 2012, 109, 16492– 16497
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        208
        Dicyanovinylnaphthalenes for neuroimaging of amyloids and relationships of electronic structures and geometries to binding affinities
        Petric, Andrej; Johnson, Scott A.; Pham, Hung V.; Li, Ying; Ceh, Simon; Golobic, Amalija; Agdeppa, Eric D.; Timbol, Gerald; Liu, Jie; Keum, Gyochang; Satyamurthy, Nagichettiar; Kepe, Vladimir; Houk, Kendall N.; Barrio, Jorge R.
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2012), 109 (41), 16492-16497, S16492/1-S16492/47CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        The positron-emission tomog. (PET) probe 2-(1-[6-[(2-fluoroethyl)(methyl)amino]-2-naphthyl]ethylidene) (FDDNP) is used for the noninvasive brain imaging of amyloid-β (Aβ) and other amyloid aggregates present in Alzheimer's disease and other neurodegenerative diseases. A series of FDDNP analogs has been synthesized and characterized using spectroscopic and computational methods. The binding affinities of these mols. have been measured exptl. and explained through the use of a computational model. The analogs were created by systematically modifying the donor and the acceptor sides of FDDNP to learn the structural requirements for optimal binding to Aβ aggregates. FDDNP and its analogs are neutral, environmentally sensitive, fluorescent mols. with high dipole moments, as evidenced by their spectroscopic properties and dipole moment calcns. The preferred soln.-state conformation of these compds. is directly related to the binding affinities. The extreme cases were a nonplanar analog t-butyl-FDDNP, which shows low binding affinity for Aβ aggregates (520 nM Ki) in vitro and a nearly planar tricyclic analog cDDNP, which displayed the highest binding affinity (10 pM Ki). Using a previously published x-ray crystallog. model of 1,1-dicyano-2-[6-(dimethylamino)naphthalen-2-yl]propene (DDNP) bound to an amyloidogenic Aβ peptide model, the binding affinity is inversely related to the distortion energy necessary to avoid steric clashes along the internal surface of the binding channel.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsFKltrrK&md5=a2d4875f1ad3219e50d3c205c8fd5cfb
      209. 209
        Reinke, A. A.; Gestwicki, J. E. Structure–activity relationships of amyloid beta-aggregation inhibitors based on curcumin: influence of linker length and flexibility Chem. Biol. Drug Des. 2007, 70, 206– 215
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        209
        Structure-activity relationships of amyloid beta-aggregation inhibitors based on curcumin: influence of linker length and flexibility
        Reinke, Ashley A.; Gestwicki, Jason E.
        Chemical Biology & Drug Design (2007), 70 (3), 206-215CODEN: CBDDAL; ISSN:1747-0277. (Blackwell Publishing Ltd.)
        Self-assembly of amyloid beta into fibrillar plaques is characteristic of Alzheimer's disease, and oligomers of this peptide are believed to be involved in neurodegeneration. Natural org. dyes, such as congo red and curcumin, bind tightly to amyloid beta and, at higher concns., block its self-assembly. The ability of these mols. to prevent amyloid accumulation has generated interest in understanding which of their structural features contribute to inhibitory potency. In general, amyloid beta ligands tend to be flat, planar mols. with substituted arom. end groups; however, a comprehensive structure-activity study has not been reported. To better understand these ligands, the authors surveyed the effect of three prominent features on inhibition of amyloid aggregation: the presence of two arom. end groups, the substitution pattern of these aroms., and the length and flexibility of the linker region. The authors found that modification of any one of the modules has profound effects on activity. Further, the authors report that the optimal length of the linker lies within a surprisingly narrow regime (6-19 Å). These results offer insight into the key chem. features required for inhibiting amyloid beta aggregation. In turn, these findings help define the nature of the docking site for small mols. on the amyloid beta surface.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtVels7rO&md5=9fb830c8d1dda285aa6d50c88a03ff27
      210. 210
        Wolfe, L. S.; Calabrese, M. F.; Nath, A.; Blaho, D. V.; Miranker, A. D.; Xiong, Y. Protein-induced photophysical changes to the amyloid indicator dye thioflavin T Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 2010, 107, 16863– 16868
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        210
        Protein-induced photophysical changes to the amyloid indicator dye thioflavin T
        Wolfe, Leslie S.; Calabrese, Matthew F.; Nath, Abhinav; Blaho, Dorottya V.; Miranker, Andrew D.; Xiong, Yong
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2010), 107 (39), 16863-16868, S16863/1-S16863/4CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
        The small mol. thioflavin T (ThT) is a defining probe for the identification and mechanistic study of amyloid fiber formation. As such, ThT is fundamental to investigations of serious diseases such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson disease, and type II diabetes. For each disease, a different protein undergoes conformational conversion to a β-sheet rich fiber. The fluorescence of ThT exhibits an increase in quantum yield upon binding these fibers. Despite its widespread use, the structural basis for binding specificity and for the changes to the photophys. properties of ThT remain poorly understood. Here, we report the co-crystal structures of ThT with two alternative states of β-2 microglobulin (β2m); one monomeric, the other an amyloid-like oligomer. In the latter, the dye intercalates between β-sheets orthogonal to the β-strands. Importantly, the fluorophore is bound in such a manner that a photophys. relevant torsion is limited to a range of angles generally assocd. with low, not high, quantum yield. Quantum mech. assessment of the fluorophore shows the electronic distribution to be strongly stabilized by arom. interactions with the protein. Monomeric β2m gives little increase in ThT fluorescence despite showing three fluorophores, at two binding sites, in configurations generally assocd. with high quantum yield. Our efforts fundamentally extend existing understanding about the origins of amyloid-induced photophys. changes. Specifically, the β-sheet interface that characterizes amyloid acts both sterically and electronically to stabilize the fluorophore's ground state electronic distribution. By preventing the fluorophore from adopting its preferred excited state configuration, nonradiative relaxation pathways are minimized and quantum yield is increased.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXht1OlsLfJ&md5=cee6125bc69a3965da8db55138c002fa
      211. 211
        Krebs, M. R.; Bromley, E. H.; Donald, A. M. The binding of thioflavin-T to amyloid fibrils: localisation and implications J. Struct. Biol. 2005, 149, 30– 37
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        211
        The binding of thioflavin-T to amyloid fibrils: localisation and implications
        Krebs, M. R. H.; Bromley, E. H. C.; Donald, A. M.
        Journal of Structural Biology (2005), 149 (1), 30-37CODEN: JSBIEM; ISSN:1047-8477. (Elsevier)
        Amyloid fibrils are a polymeric form of protein, involving a continuous β-sheet with the strands perpendicular to the long axis of the fibril. Although typically implicated in diseases such as Alzheimer's disease and the transmissible spongiform encephalopathies, non disease-assocd. protein can also be converted into amyloid fibrils. Traditionally, amyloid fibrils are identified via the use of specific dyes such as Congo red and thioflavin-T, although their specificity is ill understood. Recently, solns. of bovine insulin and bovine β-lactoglobulin have been found to form spherulites, micron-sized spherical structures contg. radially arranged amyloid fibrils. When studied by confocal microscopy using polarized laser light and thioflavin-T, a consistent pattern of emission, rather than a uniform disk, was obsd. This suggests the dye binds in a specific, regular fashion to amyloid fibrils. Confocal microscopy studies of thioflavin-T aligned in stretched poly-vinyl alc. films showed that the dye dipole excitation axis lies parallel to the long mol. axis. Therefore, thioflavin-T binds to amyloid fibrils such that their long axes are parallel. We propose binding occurs in channels' that run along the length of the β-sheet. Steric interactions between dye mols. and side chains indicate why thioflavin-T fluoresces more intensely when bound to amyloid fibrils and can explain why this interaction with amyloid fibrils is specific, but with varying efficiency.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjvFGj&md5=c3110e632f450a1e2287df4fbc014c3e
      212. 212
        Klunk, W. E.; Debnath, M. L.; Pettegrew, J. W. Development of small molecule probes for the beta-amyloid protein of Alzheimer’s disease Neurobiol. Aging 1994, 15, 691– 698
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        212
        Development of small molecule probes for the beta-amyloid protein of Alzheimer's disease
        Klunk, William E.; Debnath, Manik L.; Pettegrew, Jay W.
        Neurobiology of Aging (1994), 15 (6), 691-8CODEN: NEAGDO; ISSN:0197-4580.
        This study describes the synthesis and in vitro testing of small mol. probes that may eventually prove useful as markers of amyloid deposition in living patients. The prototype agent, Chrysamine G (CG), is a deriv. of Congo red. CG binds synthetic beta-amyloid well in vitro, as does a fluorinated deriv. The mechanism of binding appears to be the same as Congo red-through a bidentate attachment spanning several amyloid peptide chains. CG is much more lipophilic than Congo red and crosses the blood-brain barrier in normal mice, achieving a brain/blood ratio over 10/1. There was no acute toxicity in mice at doses 10 times those used in the distribution studies. CG appears to be a relatively high affinity probe for beta-amyloid that appears to have low toxicity and can cross the blood-brain barrier. These characteristics are promising for development of in vivo amyloid probes similar to CG.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXis1Crur0%253D&md5=39b76e039c4831218445956e2eee3c9e
      213. 213
        Inouye, H.; Kirschner, D. A. Alzheimer’s beta-amyloid: insights into fibril formation and structure from Congo red binding Subcell. Biochem. 2005, 38, 203– 224
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        213
        Alzheimer's β-amyloid: Insights into fibril formation and structure from congo red binding
        Inouye, Hideyo; Kirschner, Daniel A.
        Subcellular Biochemistry (2005), 38 (Alzheimer's Disease: Cellular and Molecular Aspects of Amyloid β), 203-224CODEN: SBCBAG; ISSN:0306-0225. (Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.)
        A review. We consider here the chem. of Congo red (CR), its binding equil. to Alzheimer's β-amyloid, and the kinetics of β-amyloid formation. Spectroscopic UV/Vis measurements for the pH- and time-dependence binding of CR to Aβ analogs are analyzed by Scatchard binding and the theory of nucleation-dependent fibril formation. CR likely binds electrostatically to the imidazolium sidechains of histidine residues that are exposed at the surface of amyloid fibrils. As revealed by at. models of the Aβ protofilament, such as the nanotube β-helix and parallel β-sheet, the regular arrangement of histidines likely acts as a template for the end-to-end J-aggregation of CR mols., which produces a red shift in UV/Vis absorption.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXotFaktrs%253D&md5=09488750b42cdd5a496c599433b1a391
      214. 214
        Mukrasch, M. D.; Biernat, J.; von Bergen, M.; Griesinger, C.; Mandelkow, E.; Zweckstetter, M. Sites of tau important for aggregation populate {beta}-structure and bind to microtubules and polyanions J. Biol. Chem. 2005, 280, 24978– 24986
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      215. 215
        Akoury, E.; Gajda, M.; Pickhardt, M.; Biernat, J.; Soraya, P.; Griesinger, C.; Mandelkow, E.; Zweckstetter, M. Inhibition of tau filament formation by conformational modulation J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 2853– 2862
